intro: Brassica campestris stirps pabularia, commonly known as wild cabbage, is a biennial or short-lived perennial plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, four-petaled flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, with alternate, rough, hairy leaves that are lobed or toothed. It prefers moist, disturbed soils and is often found in fields, roadsides, and waste areas. Its botanical features make it a common weed in agricultural settings.
